                    Figure 2        Brain MRI and magnetic resonance angiography




                  Diffusion-weighted images reveal restricted diffusion in the bilateral anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and right middle cerebral artery
                  territories (A–C). Magnetic resonance angiography suggests severe narrowing of the right distal internal carotid artery (ICA) and
                  poor visualization of both ACAs (D, arrows). The pituitary macroadenoma was partially hyperintense on T1-weighted images (E),
                  which was indicative of intratumoral hemorrhage, with enhancement of the peritumoral surface (F). The pituitary adenoma
                  extended to the cavernous sinus causing bilateral compression of the intracavernous ICA, worse on the right (E, arrows).

                       Figure 3       Transcranial Doppler findings before and after surgical removal of the pituitary tumor




                    (A) Transcranial Doppler sonography before surgery demonstrates severe narrowing of bilateral middle cerebral arteries
                    and anterior cerebral arteries, worse on the right, and increases in mean and peak flow velocities in the bilateral posterior
                    cerebral arteries, which indicates the development of collaterals through posterior communicating arteries. (B) The blood
                    flow of these arteries became normal after surgical intervention. ACA 5 anterior cerebral artery; MCA 5 middle cerebral
                    artery; PCA 5 posterior cerebral artery.
